Message.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?
Message.Msg: In politics and message boards, it is hold your nose and commit, despite issues of spam. The spam argument really is not valid, since for any but the small population of the stupid and the naïve it is easily recognizable. Some even waste their time openly exposing spam generated topics targeted, apparently, only to the naïve. Those who suggest Facebook and other similar message boards either discount or are in deception mode of the issue of privacy. When talking about money matters do you really want your true identity exposed? Yahoo message boards are the ONLY currently available source for talking about most all companies linked to their financial information. As far as any interpretation goes of shutting them down it would be to disadvantage small investors in a return to a level of information sharing availability not seen since the 1980’s and the dawn of widespread Internet use. It would be a huge benefit to those who wish to control the widespread availability of financial information. There have been from time to time very lucid posts on what to expect in the investment world on Yahoo message boards. So it would seem that one of the reasons for shutting down Yahoo message boards is to see that such information is no longer available except to insiders. There is also the issue of criminal activity in the financial sector, which gets a lot of exposure by many who post on Yahoo message boards. Could it be that such exposure is unwanted? We wouldn’t want such information to see the light of day, now would we? So just who do those represent that want criminal enterprises to remain untouched, as they currently are in the financial sector? If you think otherwise please DO provide your alternatives (other than Facebook).

Topic.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?

Message.Msg: Yahoo put a lot of time and money to upgrade the Yahoo message boards if they are now all of a sudden planning to get rid of it! Now, how could that make sense??

Topic.Title: "Man-up" Yahoo workforce!

Message.Msg: With all the opinions about whether it is "fair" to make "working moms" work at an office rather than home, a basic reality is being ignored. Only about 500 YAHOO! employees were working from home. The CEO had an audit done which showed "teleworkers" were not logging on at the start of core hours, nor working until the end of their particular work hours. In short, data showed these employees were (1) not putting in a basic core hour work day, (2) there was no way to measure their daily "accomplishments", and (3) accountability was absent. As for this whole dialogue that this is "unfair to women", I'd ask when it became required that women be able to avoid being physically at work, and all that it entails (dressing, commuting, attending meetings, face-to-face communications, etc.). Do females with children need special treatment? Accusations of sexism make popular television and print media. How many of the 500 are "working women" with children at home? If they need to be home, perhaps they need another job with another employer. The rise in the stock price says it all.

Topic.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?

Message.Msg: Interesting post. Lots to ponder. Spam is rampant on the boards. On any given day you have to scroll through many spam posts to get to the 'lucid' posts. On the issue of privacy, well let's just say that even though you post here and believe it is private, in my experience, IT"S NOT. It does work in other venues. Take a platform like Stocktwits...pretty much all there are 'known; to each other. They do post under id's other than their name for the most part, but they do not 'hide' who they are. I'm sure there are many other examples of platforms where do no HAVE to hide who they are for fear of being attacked. You have entirely skipped over the major issue with these boards which is they are being 'conrolled' by very few people using multiple id's. These id's abuse, harass, bully & otherwise make it extremely uncomfortable to legitimately post here. People hide on Yahoo Finance because there is an element of abuse here. When I first viewed these boards, I said there was no way in HELLLL that I would ever post here. Everyone was arguing, accusing each other of being other id's. But, what can I say, I got sucked in., not knowing the 'game' that was at play here. We were in the middle of Yang trying to pull a 'Dell', with Silver Lake, there was a lot going on & I had a new position in YHOO. Fool I was to think that I was talking to like-minded people. Is that a theory you have, that WS wants to close down the Yahoo Finance boards? I don't think it is that sinister, or maybe I don't want to believe it is? Yahoo does need to address the issues with the finance boards. Maybe they do need better moderation. I don't know.

Message.Title: Facebook News Feed
Message.Msg: Facebook is having a press event this week to show off changes in its News Feed. Anyone want to speculate what these changes are? I wonder if it might include seeding FB feeds with personalized content --- either news stories, ads, or both -- provided in part from YHOO. Certainly YHOO, with its "interest graph," would be of immense help in providing personalized stories and ads to FB users...and the deepening integration over the past several months between FB and YHOO could mean the infrastructure is in place to do this.

As long as that continues, and you have people like Marissa Mayer that want to shut people up by taking away their ability to communicate the only conclusion that can be arrived at is that the fox is guarding the henhouse. Topic.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?

Message.Msg: Yahoo has bigger problems than the functionality, look/feel of their finance message boards. By deleting urls which link to contrarian analysis, particularly of pink sheet fraud promoters WHILE allowing both the spam bots and the actual paid advertising from the stock shill firms Yahoo potentially opens itself to being joined as a recovery defendant for any tout firm hit with a civil suit. Step 1: Yahoo advertiser penalized in SEC action. Step 2: Yahoo records reveal suppression of message board postings against that advertiser (Yahoo facilitates their activities as it were) at this point whether it's automated or discretionary is irrelevant. Step 3: Plaintiffs, recognizing that the touts are long gone and damages unrecoverable, attempts to join Yahoo in the "I"ve been swindled" case. Step 4: ?? Winning isn't everything, sometimes just shining a bright light can be cringe worthy. Bottom Line: Enabling the stock fraud promoters while silencing the MB critics is a risk I wouldn't want my management to take

Topic.Title: Finance Message Boards

Message.Msg: Here is an excerpt from the announcement: Pay attention to where it says "Message Boards" The 7 products that are set to be discontinued include: Yahoo App Search, Yahoo Sports IQ, Yahoo Clues, Yahoo Message Boards, Yahoo Updates API, Yahoo Avatars, and the Yahoo app for Blackberry. The Blackberry app will continue to be listed in the Blackberry App World until April 1st. Then it will no longer be available for download, and it will no longer receive any support from Yahoo.

Topic.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?

Message.Msg: Please provide the TITLE of a credible Internet article to support your statement. It was an interesting exercise to find out who is running this company currently when the prospect of closing down Yahoo message boards was posted because of what you contend is a rumor. It seems like it was Carol Bartz previously, who also was from Wisconsin. According to one source she was also a supporter for the current POTUS. That probably has nothing to do with the reason she was fired as it seems liberal politics are a requirement for entry in the mega-corporate world. It is not a good sign when large corporations like Yahoo place a flaming liberal, like Marissa Mayer, at the helm, but it is no surprise. It seems that this is the direction most large corporations are headed, and have been for a LONG time. That’s why this country’s Founders had great misgivings that their efforts to create an environment of liberty would be lasting, particularly when it comes to corporate power. The one-world agenda, to the detriment of what this country SAYS it stands for will, if left unchecked, result in ever increasing tyranny, not that the American variety of tyrants think it will have any effect on their ability to achieve total control. The Internet and the age of the computer have been hailed as a boon to the ability of the world’s populations to create an environment for liberty to thrive, but there are those who are feverishly attempting to squash it with their liberal drivel meant to deceive enough people to garner support to that end.

Topic.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?

Message.Msg: “There is spam throughout the finance msg boards. I am not exaggerating.” Since it is unknown which message boards you visit, perhaps that is your experience, or maybe just a couple of obvious spam posts sets you off hyperventilating. Here’s a primer for you on how to recognize spam, and to just ignore it. 1. An obvious plug to get you to visit a website which will provide you a way to get rich quick. 2. A bunch of glowing one-liners backing up the glowing claims of success for those who say they visited the cited website. 3. An advisory that your computer has been attacked with a virus, provided you have a good program that can detect it. 4. Many posts stating essentially the same thing about the high quality of the advice and a stream of screen names issuing from the same source and most probably the same persion. Hopefully that will relieve you of your naïveté and get you to calm down every time you detect spam on a message board. Just ignore it. Most everybody else does.

Topic.Title: Who exactly wants Yahoo message boards shut down?

Message.Msg: LOL. I know how to recognize spam...thanks for the primer though. : ) Do I really sound like I am hyperventilating. Hardly. I don't let it bother me... I do as I assume others do and ignore the user. Simple enough. All I said was it was visible and there was plenty of it. Maybe you need to relax. Priceless, my 'naïveté'. There are many others who make a far bigger deal about spam on this board. I have to wonder why you have singled me out. Well, no I guess I know why.
